Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the step-parent needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: A new furniture order comes in, and the carpenter should estimate material requirements and order supplies as needed
Story: I was still in my work boots, sawdust clinging to my jeans, when I got the call from the store manager. My stepson, Jamie, had been caught slipping a candy bar into his pocket. As a step-parent, I knew I had to teach him right from wrong, to show him that honesty matters, even when it’s hard. But as I listened to the manager’s stern voice, my phone buzzed again—my boss, reminding me that the new furniture order needed my attention. I was supposed to estimate materials and place the order before the supplier closed for the weekend. If I missed it, the whole project would be delayed, and my reputation as a reliable carpenter would take a hit. I could feel the pressure mounting—Jamie needed me to be present, to guide him through this mistake, but my work demanded my focus, too. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility of shaping a young life and the duty to my craft and clients. I stood in the parking lot, heart pounding, caught between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more in that moment.
